summary: This is a letter from Ghislaine Maxwell's defense attorney, Bobbi C. Sternheim, to Judge Alison J. Nathan, raising serious concerns about Maxwell's conditions of confinement at the Metropolitan Detention Center (MDC). The letter alleges Maxwell is being subjected to sleep deprivation via disruptive flashlight surveillance every 15 minutes at night and details a recent incident where she was discovered with a black eye, which staff threatened to punish her for. The document includes a court order for the government to investigate and respond to these allegations.

events.title: Discovery of Maxwell's Black Eye
events.description: Ghislaine Maxwell discovered she had a bruise/black eye over her left eye while detained at the MDC. MDC staff later confronted her about it, threatening to place her in the SHU if she did not reveal its cause.

events.title: Defense Letter Filed Regarding Jail Conditions
events.description: Defense attorney Bobbi C. Sternheim filed a letter with the court detailing allegations of sleep deprivation and improper treatment of Ghislaine Maxwell at the MDC, including the black eye incident.

events.title: Government Response Deadline Ordered
events.description: Judge Nathan ordered the government to confer with MDC legal counsel and provide responses to specific questions about Maxwell's sleeping conditions and surveillance by this date.

locations: United States Courthouse, 40 Foley Square, New York, NY 10007
Special Housing Unit (SHU) - referenced as a potential punitive location within MDC
keyFacts: Ghislaine Maxwell's defense alleges she is subjected to sleep deprivation at the MDC via guards shining a flashlight/strobe light into her cell every 15 minutes throughout the night under the pretext of checking her breathing.

Maxwell was discovered with a visible bruise or 'black eye' over her left eye while in custody. MDC staff threatened to place her in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) if she did not explain how she got it, though she reported being unaware of its cause.

The defense contends Maxwell's official classification is 'CC1-Mh,' designating her as an inmate with no significant mental health care needs, contradicting any official justification for heightened surveillance related to suicide risk.

Judge Alison J. Nathan issued a court order requiring the government to investigate and report on the specifics of Maxwell's nighttime surveillance and the basis for it, and to explore providing her with appropriate eye covering.
